statement:
A topological space $X$ is compact if and only if every net in $X$ has
an accumulation point.

Suppose $X$ is compact and let $(x_\alpha)_{\alpha\in A}$ be a net in
$X$. For each $\alpha\in A$, put
$E_\alpha={\{x_\beta:\beta\geq\alpha\}}$; the collection
${\{\overline{E_\alpha}:\alpha\in A\}}$ of closed subsets of $X$ has the
finite intersection property, for given $\alpha_1,\ldots,\alpha_n\in A$,
because $A$ is directed, there exists $\beta\in A$ satisfying
$\beta\geq\alpha_i$ for each $i\in{\{1,\ldots,n\}}$, so that
$x_\beta\in\bigcap_{i=1}^n\overline{E_{\alpha_i}}$. Therefore, by
compactness, $\bigcap_{\alpha\in A}\overline{E_\alpha}\neq\emptyset$;
let $x$ be a point of this intersection. If $U$ is any open subset of
$X$ and $\alpha\in A$, then because $x\in\overline{E_\alpha}$,
$E_\alpha\cap U\neq\emptyset$, and thus there exists
$\beta\geq\alpha\in A$ for which $x_\beta\in U$. It follows that $x$ is
an accumulation point of $(x_\alpha)$. For the converse, assume that $X$
fails to be compact, and let ${\{U_i:i\in I\}}$ be an open cover of $X$
with no finite subcover. If $B$ is the set of finite subsets of $I$,
then $B$ is directed by inclusion. For each set $S\in B$, let $x_S$ be a
point in the complement of $\bigcup_{i\in S}U_i$. We contend that the
net $(x_S)_{S\in B}$ has no accumulation points; indeed, given $x\in X$,
we may select $i_0\in I$ such that $x\in U_{i_0}$; if $S\in B$ is such
that $i_0\in S$, that is, if $S\geq{\{i_0\}}$, then by construction,
$x_S\notin U_{i_0}$, establishing our contention.

The following conditions on a topological space $X$ are equivalent:

1.  $X$ is compact;

2.  every net in $X$ has an accumulation point;

3.  every net in $X$ has a convergent subnet;

The preceding theorem establishes the equivalence of (1) and (2), while
that of (2) and (3) is established in the entry on accumulation points
and convergent subnets.
names: compactness and accumulation points of nets
